docs.lead_paragraph: Children, who receive as many as 11 vaccinations routinely, are not in danger of having their immune system overwhelmed, according to a study published today. ''Current studies do not support the hypothesis that multiple vaccines overwhelm, weaken or 'use up' the immune system,'' said the report from Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and several other institutions.

headline.main: Study Says Multiple Infant Vaccines Are Safe

docs.abstract: Study shows that children, who receive as many as 11 vaccinations routinely, are not in danger of having their immune system overwhelmed (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The crash diets that boxers use to make their weight limits leave them mean and lean, but no better off in the ring, according to an article in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine. In the study, 16 amateur boxers were put through a series of exercises at their training weight and then after they dieted to get down to their ''championship'' weight. They shed an average of 5 percent of their body weight, mostly by skipping rope and cutting down on food in the week before weigh-in, and cutting down on fluid intake for the final 24 hours.

headline.main: Reaching Fighting Weight Can Be Costly

docs.lead_paragraph: When I complained to my son Erik about things I can no longer remember, he replied: ''What do you expect? With all you've stuffed into your head all these years, something is bound to fall out.'' Along with the many notes on my fridge reminding me of things I have to do is a New Yorker cartoon depicting an elephant covered with Post-its, who tells his unadorned companion, ''As I get older, I find I rely more and more on these sticky notes to remind me.''

headline.main: Better Memory: It Doesn't Come in a Pill

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on memory, memory decline and memory disorders; guidelines for staying sharp (M)2

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of measles cases in the Western Hemisphere fell by 99 percent over the last decade, thanks to an aggressive vaccination campaign led by the Pan American Health Organization, according to an article in The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The virus that causes the disease remains common in Haiti and the Dominican Republic, but the number of cases in the 41 countries that report to the Pan American organization fell from about 250,000 in 1990 to 1,754 in 2000. And only 423 confirmed cases had been reported for 2001 through mid-November, the article said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, a man came to me for a psychiatric consultation after he had lost his job. He explained that he had recently been fired -- or, in the pyrotechnic language of Wall Street that he used, his ''desk had been blown up.'' The company had shut down his investment group's computers with no warning and, after permitting the executives to gather up a few personal possessions, security officers had marched them to the door. The company called it a ''business restructuring,'' but it sounded more like a police raid to me.

headline.main: A Diagnosis Not Exactly In the Book

docs.abstract: Dr Anna Fels article holds assumption of personal responsibility for ill fortune has become endemic in our culture; sees people turning to psychatrists in mistaken hope that 'self-knowledge' will remedy fate; says task of psychiatrist lies in separating pathology from normal variation (M)2

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Cloud, a lawyer in Cincinnati, has fallen asleep while talking to clients, while eating dinner, even while meeting with a judge. Mr. Cloud, 58, has suffered for much of his adult life from narcolepsy, a little-understood sleep disorder that afflicts as many as 100,000 to 200,000 Americans. People with the condition are prone to sudden, uncontrollable attacks of intense sleepiness.

headline.main: A Quiet Revolution for Those Prone to Nodding Off

docs.lead_paragraph: Heart disease is often viewed as more of a man's disease than a woman's, yet more women die in the hospital after a heart attack than men. Some studies have suggested that the reason for the difference is that women get less aggressive treatment. But new research has found that even when women did get the best therapies, they still fared worse than men.

headline.main: Heart Attacks' High Toll on Women

docs.abstract: New research shows that heart disease takes higher toll on women than men, even when women receive best and most aggressive therapies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Older women who consume high levels of vitamin A through supplements and fortified foods may be increasing their risk of hip fracture, according to a Harvard study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Dr. Diane Feskanich, who directed the study, said that earlier studies had found that extremely high doses of retinol, the active form of vitamin A, can cause bone thinning. Her study looked at the long-term effects of consuming near or slightly more than the current recommended maximum retinol allowance of 3,000 micrograms a day.

headline.main: How Excess Vitamin A Can Hit the Hips

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's some consolation for the Oscar nominees for best screenplay who don't get the prize this March: odds are that they'll live longer than the winner, according to a new study in The British Journal of Medicine. The study, by Dr. Donald A. Redelmeier and Dr. Sheldon M. Singh of Sunnybrook and Women's Hospital in Toronto, was included in the journal's year-end roundup of quirky research. Many studies have shown that more successful people have longer lives, including work by Dr. Redelmeier and Dr. Singh that found Oscar-winning actors outlived mere nominees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The report of his death was an exaggeration. After a seven-month wait, Larry Kramer, the author and H.I.V.-positive AIDS activist, received a liver transplant on Dec. 21. The 12-hour operation, performed at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center by Dr. John Fung, Dr. Ashok Jain and Dr. Bijan Eghtesad, went according to plan.

headline.main: Writer Chuckles Over Report of His Demise
